message.content: We refer to biology articles on meiosis for help. Nondisjunction is the failure of homologous chromosomes or sister chromatids to separate properly during cell division. In meiosis, this can occur during either meiosis I or meiosis II. The observed ratio indicates that two gametes had an extra chromosome (n+1) and two gametes were missing a chromosome (n-1). This suggests nondisjunction occurred during Anaphase I, where homologous chromosomes failed to separate properly.

We refer to biology resources for help. Nondisjunction occurs when homologous chromosomes or sister chromatids fail to separate during meiosis. The fact that there are 2 gametes with 24 chromosomes and 2 gametes with 22 chromosomes indicates that there was a failure of a homologous pair to separate during meiosis I, specifically in anaphase I.

We refer to textbook or lecture notes on meiosis for help. Nondisjunction occurs when homologous chromosomes or sister chromatids fail to separate during cell division. In this case, the gametes produced have an uneven number of chromosomes. This suggests a failure of homologous chromosomes to separate properly during anaphase I of meiosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on meiosis for help. Nondisjunction occurs when homologous chromosomes fail to separate during meiosis, resulting in one daughter cell receiving an extra chromosome and the other missing one. This leads to aneuploidy in the resulting gametes. The given scenario shows two gametes with 24 chromosomes (extra chromosome) and two gametes with 22 chromosomes (missing chromosome), indicating that nondisjunction occurred during Anaphase I.

We refer to biology articles for help. Nondisjunction is the failure of homologous chromosomes to separate during meiosis I or failure of sister chromatids to separate during meiosis II. The gametes produced in the mouse model showed an unequal number of chromosomes, with 2 gametes having an extra chromosome and 2 gametes missing a chromosome. This indicates that nondisjunction occurred during meiosis I, specifically during anaphase I when homologous chromosomes should separate but didn't, resulting in an unequal division of chromosomes.

We refer to biology textbooks and resources for help. Nondisjunction occurs when homologous chromosomes or sister chromatids fail to separate during meiosis. Based on the gametes produced in the mouse model, nondisjunction likely occurred during Anaphase I, where homologous chromosomes did not separate properly, resulting in gametes with abnormal chromosome numbers.

We refer to biology articles for help. Nondisjunction occurs during anaphase I or II of meiosis, when chromosomes fail to separate correctly. The given ratio of gametes with 24 and 22 chromosomes each suggest that nondisjunction occurred during anaphase I, where homologous chromosomes fail to separate.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on meiosis for help. Nondisjunction occurs in either anaphase I or II of meiosis, when homologous chromosomes or sister chromatids fail to separate. In this case, the mouse model produced an equal number of gametes with 24 and 22 chromosomes, suggesting that the nondisjunction occurred during anaphase I, when homologous chromosomes fail to separate.

We refer to the Khan Academy article on meiosis for help. Nondisjunction occurs when chromosomes fail to separate properly during meiosis. The ratio of 2 gametes with 24 chromosomes each and 2 gametes with 22 chromosomes each suggests that a pair of chromosomes did not separate during anaphase I, resulting in one cell receiving 24 chromosomes and the other cell receiving 22 chromosomes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on meiosis for help. Nondisjunction occurs when homologous chromosomes fail to separate during meiosis, resulting in gametes with an abnormal chromosome number. In this case, the gametes produced have either 24 chromosomes or 22 chromosomes, indicating that nondisjunction occurred during meiosis I in the anaphase stage, where homologous chromosomes fail to separate properly.
